node.title: ANU college denies it failed in its duty of care over former student's sexual assault
node.alt: External view of John XXIII College at the Australian National University.
node.description: The Australian National University's John XXIII College is appealing the ACT Supreme Court's finding that it failed in its duty of care after a former student was sexually assaulted.
node.content:
["The Australian National University's John XXIII College has appealed against a ruling which awarded a former student more than $400,000, and found the college had\u00a0breached its duty of care to the\u00a0young woman.", "A former ANU student who attended the college, was raped in an alleyway\u00a0near Canberra nightspot Mooseheads in 2015, after she and other students were made to leave the college after a drinking session.", "The night had begun at the college with an event known as \"pub golf\", which involved bar-hopping and drinking a certain number of drinks in order to make \"par\".", "The woman has no memory of the assault and only became aware of it\u00a0days later when a friend told her the other party had been joking about the incident.", "The woman took a civil claim to the ACT Supreme Court, seeking damages for psychological injury and economic loss arising from her diverging from her original career path.", "The court found there had been a breach of duty of care by the college and awarded her $420,201.57 in compensation for damages, and past and future loss of earnings.", "But on Monday, lawyers for the college took aim at the ruling, disputing the facts and the finding that the college was responsible.", "The two main issues in the case, were whether the college breached its duty of care by forcing the intoxicated students to leave the university campus, and if there was a further breach in the later handling of the situation by staff.", "", "
\"Pub golf\" involves a series of \"holes\" in which participants have to drink a certain amount to make a \"par\".(Supplied)
", "
College says woman attended event of her own volition
", "Counsel for the college, Michael Windsor, told the court the woman was a 20-year-old adult at the time of\u00a0the events, not a school student, who had willingly participated in the social event at the college.", "\"She didn't do so by reason of being forced to or it being imposed on her, she did so freely,\"\u00a0Windsor said.", "", "
The woman's barrister said the college had knowledge of the drinking culture on campus.(Supplied)
", "He said the college could not impose on the autonomy of an individual, and to have tried to prevent her from leaving the premises would have exposed the college to indiscriminate liability.", "Mr Windsor said the woman had been distressed but had not suffered mental harm, and her move from her job in business, to a bid to study medicine, was a \"lifestyle change\".", "But the woman's barrister, Fiona McLeod, told the court the college had been well aware of the excessive drinking culture and had condoned it.", "She said there was evidence it was a Thursday routine, and the usual words when people were intoxicated, were \"it's time to move out\".", "Ms McLeod told the court this was not a fanciful notion of possible harm, this was actual knowledge of excessive drinking.", "She said the college owed a duty of care to the woman, including in the handling of the incident in the aftermath, and had failed.", "The hearing will continue later this week."]
